content: Which British author wrote the dystopian novel "1984" that introduced concepts such as Big Brother and Newspeak?

The British author who wrote the dystopian novel "1984," which introduced concepts such as Big Brother and Newspeak, is George Orwell. His real name was Eric Arthur Blair, and he was born in India in 1903 before moving to England. "1984" was published in 1949 and has become a seminal work in literature, particularly in the genres of dystopian fiction and political satire. The novel portrays a totalitarian society where individualism is suppressed, and the government wields absolute control over its citizens through surveillance, propaganda, and manipulation of language. The themes and ideas presented in "1984" continue to resonate in contemporary discussions about privacy, government power, and the abuse of language for political purposes.
